BE11:11am

Neil Woodford has blocked redemptions from his £3.7bn equity income fund after serial underperformance led to an investor exodus, inflicting a serious blow to the reputation of the UK’s highest-profile fund manager.

The freeze on redemptions, exactly five years after Mr Woodford opened his eponymous fund management group, underlines his increasingly precarious position. It follows a steady stream of investor outflows, which have occurred each month for two years, with the fund shrinking by two-thirds to £3.7bn since a peak of £10.2bn in May 2017.

BE11:22am

Under the UCITS rules no more than 10% of an open ended fund’s assets can be invested in
‘ineligible securities’. This usually includes unquoted stocks, but not where there is an ‘intention to list’ within
12 months of the issue of an unquoted security. But it also means that quoted securities on an ineligible market
are classified as ‘unquoted’. Under these definitions, WEIF had around 8% invested in ineligible securities at the
end of February 2019 (proforma a transfer of unlisteds to WPCT). WEIF’s biggest remaining unlisted is
Benevolent AI (4.7% of WEIF at end April and 8.4% of WPCT). The problem with open ended redemptions is
that the more liquid holdings tend to be sold first which means the amount remaining in ineligible securities is
more likely to breach the rules. And of course redemptions signal to the wider market a need to sell holdings.
WEIF attempted to solve this problem in March 2019 by controversially issuing shares in WPCT to WEIF at
NAV in return for a portfolio of WEIF’s unquoted asserts (Atom Bank, Carrick Therapeutics, Cell Medica,
RateSetter and Spin Memory). We estimate that as a result of this transaction WEIF now holds 9% of WPCT.
This transaction fully utilised WPCT’s 10% share issuance powers at the time, but these were renewed at the
May 2019 AGM, so WPCT is free to issue a further 10% of its shares on a non-preemptive basis without
seeking additional permission from shareholders. The suspension of dealings in WEIF buys it time to get its
house in order, but has a number of broader implications:

BE11:22am

First, and most obviously, there is an immediate overhang in WPCT as these are securities that could be sold
to meet WEIF redemptions. There was no mention of a lock-up when the shares were issued to WEIF.
 Second, there are some common quoted holdings across both WPCT and WEIF, and if these are depressed
that will feed through negatively to WPCT’s NAV, although the overlap is actually relatively small – we think
today’s price action (at least on the screens) has had no more than a 1% impact on WEIF.
 Third, the impact on Woodford’s reputation as a fund manager and the resulting widening of the discount in
WPCT today to around 21% given the 9% fall in price to 69.4pp (@09:45), makes it a possible target for
predators.

BE11:22am

Fourth, WEIF owns large stakes in a number of other investment trusts/holding companies other than WPCT,
and these are also at risk from having to be sold to meet redemptions. These include Honeycomb (WEIF
holds 17.8% according to Bloomberg, price unchanged at 1115p @09:45), Oakley Capital (WEIF holds
16.3% according to Bloomberg, price unchanged at 217.5p @09:45), IP Group (WEIF holds 13.2%
according to Bloomberg, 80.10p @09:45,up 0.3%), Burford Capital (WEIF holds 6.8% according to
Bloomberg, 1508p @09:45, down 4.6%), Arix Bioscience (WEIF holds 16.5% according to Bloomberg,
138.5p @09:45, -7%) and Allied Minds (WEIF owns 19.8% according to Bloomberg, 74.8p @09:45, -6.2%).

Tom Dalgleish Never having heard of Woodford before this year, was he lionised in the media and walked on water afterwards?
jaws BE Thanks for Woodford info.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Finally it is worth making the point again that investment trusts remain the superior structure for holding
illiquid securities as this episode clearly demonstrates and which will be a concern to regulators. Investors can
at least sell their shares in WPCT if they want to, though they may not like the price, but crucially the
managers will not be forced to sell any holdings from WPCT.

BE11:23am

As we mentioned above the relatively small
overlap between WEIF and WPCT means there is not likely to be a big additional hit to NAV to WPCT. But
there is a risk that additional stock in WPCT will be issued to WEIF in exchange for unquoted holdings.
However, in our view that would be very difficult to justify from a corporate governance perspective, given
huge uncertainty over their value and the even bigger conflicts of interests than those that existed in March
when the first transaction took place.

BE11:23am

With the discount at current levels WPCT looks vulnerable to discount
players, but as a potential wind up play it is dominated by unquoted holdings from which it could take years to unlock value. Investors are at least spared management fees with WPCT, with Woodford only receiving a potential performance fee, but it is significantly below its hurdle, so WPCT is effectively fee free. Should the
board decide to fire the mangers, the notice period is just 3 months.

More stable but not immune: We have lowered our dividend forecasts for
NewRiver REIT and take a more cautious view of the future
performance of its portfolio. We therefore downgrade our rating from Buy
to Hold at a reduced price target of 248p from 265p. We regard the
company’s decision to keep the dividend flat at 21.6p as reasonable.
However, we expect that it will fully cover the dividend only for the next
fiscal year, rather than the current year, as it has targeted.

There's also a big RBC sector note out overnight.

BE11:49am

We initiate coverage on the European Autos group with a positive bias on car-makers and a more cautious view on suppliers. While we acknowledge near-term cyclical pressures, the market is valuing Daimler, Renault and VW with no terminal value. Our positive view on the car-makers is supported in part by our proprietary EV survey suggesting strong consumer demand and a willingness to pay more.

BE11:50am

EV as in electric vehicles not enterprise value.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

EV fears look overblown. Our proprietary survey suggests more robust demand for EVs in Europe and consumer willingness to pay more for them. Furthermore, our analysis shows that meeting and exceeding CO2 requirements is achievable and EV costs are manageable, especially after factoring in falling battery costs and increased price capture given cost of ownership benefits. Our work shows that premium battery electric vehicle (BEV) makers are already profitable and the mass- market should reach break-even in 2023-2024.

BE11:50am

China and Emerging Markets to fuel long-term growth but near- term pressures persist. Our global production forecast is below third- party vendor projections. As a result, we see near-term pressure for suppliers, which are levered more to global production than the OEMs. All that said, we believe that over the medium-to-long term, China and Emerging Market growth should offset weakness in Developed Markets (DM). Importantly, our scenario analysis illustrates that OEM profitability should not be compromised given that China margins are higher than DM margins and China represents 70% of emerging market unit sales.

BE11:50am

So buy Renault, VW, Daimler.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Back-solving the current share prices suggests that Renault, VW and Daimler are valued with no terminal value: 1) Renault is currently trading at a negative EBITDA multiple when adjusted for its Nissan stake; 2) VW is trading at 1x EBITDA, but 35% of EBITDA (Porsche and Commercial Truck) should trade at greater than 5x, we see management as motivated to take action; 3) Daimler in our view is the best positioned auto-maker to weather electrification and ride-sharing secular threats.

BE11:51am

US trade disputes problematic but not catastrophic. An auto trade war is not in our base case. A 25% tariff on US imports from Europe combined with a 25% retaliatory tariff from US exports to China would mean a 6.4%, 10.4%, and 14.9% reduction in our valuations for VW, Daimler and BMW, respectively, which would still imply upside potential for VW and Daimler. We believe PSA and Renault are better positioned. For the suppliers, a global trade war would mean lower global production volumes which would disadvantage Faurecia and Valeo over Conti given its significant tyre exposure.
